On Thu, 15 Jul 2004 23:06:17 -0700 (PDT), Richardson Paul$B$5$s(B wrote:

>as a practioner of a ryu that has JUTTE I will have to
>disagree with you on this one (a little bit), only for
>its common know name (see link below for your used
>name).

I've had this conversation before -- it looks like you have, too. :) 

>When I was allowed to look in the Kukishin ryu densho
>the characters used are 十手

Yes on this we agree.  $B==<j(B are the only kanji I've ever seen used to 
write this weapon. The kanji I used in my message were $B==2|(B, the 
Ten Commandments. I used it as an example to show how ten, which is 
pronounced jyuu, becomes jikk in compound words. The Ten Commandments 
are not 'jyuu-kai', but rather 'jikkai', Ten minutes are not 
'jyuppun', but rather 'jippun', etc.

>A very close friend of  mine is a member of the Masaki
>Ryu In Japan which is famous for its Jutte and edo
>machikata jutte, they use the term Jutte (or at least
>he does when discussing the matter with me)

Here of course there can be no argument. They either use that 
pronuncation or not, and either way it's just a fact. But, jutte could 
be kind of a 'jargon' or specialized pronunciation that is used in 
that ryuu-ha only.

Alternatively, this could be a tomato - tomahto kind of thing. The 
word brings up enough discussion from time to time that it's 
probably impossible to declare with finality what is the 'right' 
pronunciation.


--
Jay Kelly
